Description: Spherical incense-burner; made in two hemispherical halves which can be locked together by a bayonet fitting to form a sphere; gymbals, a series of rings inside one another, were attached to one half, and ensured that the central saucer remained upright even when the incense-burner was rolled around; the decoration consists of roundels with palmette ornament. Made of cast brass, engraved and inlaid with silver and gold.
Curator's comments: On the origin of this type of metalware: D. Behrens-Abouseif, "Veneto-Saracenic Metalware, a Mamluk Art", Mamluk Studies Review 9 (2005) 147-172.

This type of incense-burner is sometimes described as a hand-warmer. The origins for the shape are Chinese and developed from armillary spheres used by astronomers. The dating and westward diffusion of this form are described by Ward (1990/91).
Bibliographic references: Ward 1990/91 / Incense and incense burners in Mamluk Egypt and Syria (p.74, pl.8)
La Niece, Ward et al 1995 / Veneto-Saracenic metalwork: an analysis of the bowls and incense burners in the British Museum (p.252)
Auld 2004 / Renaissance Venice, Islam and Mahmud the Kurd - a metalworking enigma (p.128)
